docs.lead_paragraph: A pediatrician says parents, not the HPV vaccine, are the major factor in teenage attitudes toward sex.

headline.main: Influencing Teenagers: Advice From a Pediatrician
headline.print_headline: Influencing Teenagers: Advice From a Pediatrician

docs.snippet: A pediatrician says parents, not the HPV vaccine, are the major factor in teenage attitudes toward sex.

docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers announced that they had found a vulnerable spot on the virus’s outer shell that might present a good vaccine target.

headline.seo: A Weak Spot in H.I.V’s Armor Raises Hope for a Vaccine
headline.main: A Weak Spot in H.I.V.’s Armor Raises Hope for a Vaccine
headline.print_headline: A Weak Spot in H.I.V.’s Armor Raises Hope for a Vaccine

docs.abstract: Dr Salim Abdool Karim study in journal Nature Medicine reports the discovery of a vulnerable spot on the outer shell of the HIV virus that may present a good target for vaccination; research into AIDS vaccines has long been stymied by the virus' rapid mutation rate.
docs.snippet: Researchers announced that they had found a vulnerable spot on the virus’s outer shell that might present a good vaccine target.

docs.lead_paragraph: Monoclonal antibodies are manufactured in the laboratory and then cloned to attach to specific disease cells without injuring healthy tissue.

headline.seo: First Mention: Monoclonal Antibodies in The New York Times

docs.abstract: New York Times first mentioned monoclonal antibodies, which are manufactured in laboratories to attack specific disease cells, on May 1, 1979.
docs.snippet: Monoclonal antibodies are manufactured in the laboratory and then cloned to attach to specific disease cells without injuring healthy tissue.
